Cables carrying 400,000 volts will run through

12.text: supporting the city as it keeps growing

13.text: and keeps demanding more and more electricity.

16.text: This project cost a billion pounds,

19.text: all to keep the lights on.

20.text: So how did we get to this?

23.text:
Back in the 1920s, electricity was generated
by hundreds of small companies

27.text: in towns and cities across the country.

29.text: They were all different and mostly incompatible:

32.text: London alone had 24 voltages and 10 frequencies.

36.text: So if you moved to the next street over,

38.text: you might have to replace all your light bulbs.

41.text: If you had any light bulbs, that is:

42.text:
the cost of electricity was out of reach of
nearly everyone.

46.text:
Now the answer might have been to do what
other countries in Europe were doing:

49.text: set up and enforce standards, regulate prices,

52.text: maybe even nationalise the power companies.

55.text: And bring the price down for everyone --

56.text: people and business. Good plan in theory,

60.text:
but the trouble was that the Prime Minister
at the time was Stanley Baldwin,

64.text: and he led the Conservative party. Politically,

67.text:
he couldn't just assume control of private
corporations!

71.text: That was something that the Other Side did.

75.text:
So the solution was a very clever and very
British compromise:

79.text:
the National Gridiron, later just National
Grid.

85.text: backed up by the government and run privately,

88.text: would construct and own the central infrastructure.

91.text:
It would build a network of transmission lines
sweeping across the country.

95.text:
The Grid would reduce the risk for the private
generating companies

98.text: and let them reach a much, much, larger market.

101.text: If they wanted to connect and reach everyone,

102.text:
they had to meet the Grid's standards for
frequency,

111.text:
The greatest story I found while I was researching
this is that

115.text: originally, there were six separate grid areas

117.text: spread all around the country, all run individually.

120.text: It was judged too risky by their managers

122.text:
to actually connect them all into one National
Grid.

127.text:
Sometimes two or maybe even three of those
grid areas were connected

130.text:
to help out if one power station somewhere
went down.

133.text:
So on the night of 29th October, 1937, without
any permission,

139.text:
the engineers in the control rooms quietly
decided

141.text:
to connect the whole country together for
an hour or two

146.text: And it worked. And a year later,

148.text: even their managers agreed: it was the only way

150.text: to make sure the lights stayed on everywhere.

153.text: And so while the level of regulation,

158.text:
as it has in pretty much every country in
the world --

and while the technology has developed to
the point

we are now in billion-pound tunnelling projects

171.text:
that mostly-private grid is what we still
